title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions such as the naming of vessels, expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, discharge of agricultural cargo residue, recording and discharging maritime liens, and various certificates of documentation for vessels. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, keeping the lifeline of freedom open during World War II, and facing dangers from enemies. President Franklin D. Roosevelt praised their role as the "Fourth Arm of Defense" during the war, with over 250,000 men and women serving in the Merchant Marine. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced dangers from submarines, mines, armed raiders, and aircraft. Over 6,800 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, and 604 were taken prisoner. Their death rate was higher than any other armed service, but they continue to serve the nation. The United States Merchant Marine faced dangers during World War II, with many members killed, wounded, or taken prisoner. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds to construct an addition to the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor in California. The Federal government will cover 50% of the costs, with an authorization of $500,000 for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The Secretary is required to record a notice of lien if a declaration is filed stating the information is true and correct. The notice must be true and correct, and copies must be sent to the vessel owner, lien claimants, and mortgagees. Declarations by non-individuals must be signed by authorized officials. Upon full discharge of the debt, the lien claimant must provide proof. The amendment requires the lien claimant to provide a certificate of discharge upon full repayment of the debt. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions regarding vessel liens, with venue based on the vessel's location or the claimant's residence. The court may award costs and attorney fees to the prevailing party. The amendment adds provisions regarding the expiration of a notice of claim of lien and clarifies that it does not affect maritime lien laws or defenses. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 46 of the United States Code. The amendment modifies notice requirements for recording and discharging liens on vessels. It also addresses the approval of surrendering documentation for vessels with liens recorded. Additionally, a technical correction is made to the Shipping Act, 1916. The Shipping Act, 1916 is amended to include exceptions provided in the Merchant Marine Act, 1936 and title 46. Effective date of the amendment is July 1, 2002. The Secretary of Transportation will determine the tonnage measurement for the small passenger vessel R/V DAVIDSON for regulatory purposes. This measurement applies when the vessel complies with specific requirements. Additionally, miscellaneous certificates of documentation are addressed. The Secretary of Transportation may issue certificates of documentation for vessels like LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER. The Secretary of Transportation may issue certificates of documentation for vessels like VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO. SEC. 9 amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, US Code to exempt SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10 allows for the issuance of certificates of documentation for 3 barges. SEC. 10 allows the Secretary of Transportation to issue certificates of documentation for three barges for use as floating platforms for launching fireworks. The barges listed are the former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY. SEC. 11. Certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE is issued by the Secretary of Transportation for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State, operated for specific purposes, and clearly identified. SEC. 12. Waiver for vessels in New World Challenge Race. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the race can transport guests without payment until 60 days after the race ends or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER can be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
